clusters.title: Trump begins second U.K. state visit under shadow of Epstein scandal

items.title: Trump begins second U.K. state visit under shadow of Epstein scandal
items.standfirst: Trump is receiving the royal treatment from King Charles on a historic second U.K. state visit, but he's been greeted also by protests over his ties to Jeffrey Epstein.
items.content: Trump is receiving the royal treatment from King Charles on a historic second U.K. state visit, but he's been greeted also by protests over his ties to Jeffrey Epstein.

items.title: Donald Trump in the UK: Protesters beam Epstein images at Windsor Castle
items.standfirst: Donald #Trump's #UK state visit is overshadowed by renewed controversy over his ties to Jeffrey #Epstein, as protests, image projections, and political fallout seem to dominate the trip.
items.content: Donald #Trump's #UK state visit is overshadowed by renewed controversy over his ties to Jeffrey #Epstein, as protests, image projections, and political fallout seem to dominate the trip.

items.title: Donald Trump to Meet King Charles, Royals at Windsor Castle for Second UK State Visit: Live Updates

items.content: U.S. President Donald Trump is in the United Kingdom for an unprecedented second state visit. Follow Newsweek for live coverage.

items.title: What is the President doing on his visit to the UK?
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump and his wife Melania are in the UK for an unprecedented second state visit.
items.content: US President Donald Trump and his wife Melania are in the UK for an unprecedented second state visit.

items.title: Trump’s second state visit to the UK will be met by royal pomp, protests
items.standfirst: The visit comes as both the US and UK leaders face fallout over the furore surrounding Jeffrey Epstein.
items.content: The visit comes as both the US and UK leaders face fallout over the furore surrounding Jeffrey Epstein.

items.title: Trump arrived in Britain on Tuesday for an unprecedented second state visit
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump arrived in Britain on Tuesday for an unprecedented second state visit, with the UK government rolling out a royal red carpet welcome to win over the mercurial leader.
items.content: US President Donald Trump arrived in Britain on Tuesday for an unprecedented second state visit, with the UK government rolling out a royal red carpet welcome to win over the mercurial leader.

items.title: Four arrests after Trump and Epstein images projected on Windsor Castle
items.standfirst: Police said four people remain in custody after the "stunt," which coincided with the US president's arrival in the UK.
items.content: Police said four people remain in custody after the "stunt," which coincided with the US president's arrival in the UK.

items.title: Images of Trump and Jeffrey Epstein projected on Windsor Castle
items.standfirst: Images and video of President Trump and convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein were projected on Windsor Castle ahead of Trump’s second state visit to the U.K. Thames Valley Police said four people were arrested in connection to the “public stunt in Windsor.”
items.content: Images and video of President Trump and convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein were projected on Windsor Castle ahead of Trump’s second state visit to the U.K. Thames Valley Police said four people were arrested in connection to the “public stunt in Windsor.”

items.content: US president to meet King Charles as royal family prepares for pomp and ceremony

items.content: Images of US President Donald Trump and the UK’s Prince Andrew with Jeffrey Epstein were projected onto Windsor Castle.

items.title: UK rolls out royal red carpet for Donald Trump's second visit
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump formally begins his unprecedented second state visit to Britain on Wednesday with the royal pomp a grand veneer to key diplomatic talks, and as difficult questions about Jeffrey Epstein linger. FRANCE 24 correspondent Bénédicte Paviot brings us the latest from the ground.
items.content: US President Donald Trump formally begins his unprecedented second state visit to Britain on Wednesday with the royal pomp a grand veneer to key diplomatic talks, and as difficult questions about Jeffrey Epstein linger. FRANCE 24 correspondent Bénédicte Paviot brings us the latest from the ground.

items.content: Microsoft and Nvidia unveiled plans to invest up to $45 billion in the UK during US President Donald Trump’s state visit.

items.title: Trump announces deadly US strike on another alleged Venezuelan drug boat
items.standfirst: President says three people killed in strike against vessel he said was transporting drugs ‘headed to the US’Donald Trump said on Monday that the United States had carried out a strike on a second Venezuelan boat and killed three alleged terrorists he claimed were transporting drugs, expanding his administration’s war against drug cartels and the scope of lethal military force to stop them.The US president gave few details about the strike, saying in a social media post that the action was on his orders and that it had happened earlier in the morning. The post was accompanied by a video clip showing the boat, which appeared to be stationary, erupting into a fireball. Continue reading...
items.content: President says three people killed in strike against vessel he said was transporting drugs ‘headed to the US’Donald Trump said on Monday that the United States had carried out a strike on a second Venezuelan boat and killed three alleged terrorists he claimed were transporting drugs, expanding his administration’s war against drug cartels and the scope of lethal military force to stop them.The US president gave few details about the strike, saying in a social media post that the action was on his orders and that it had happened earlier in the morning. The post was accompanied by a video clip showing the boat, which appeared to be stationary, erupting into a fireball. Continue reading...

items.title: U.S. military targets a second alleged Venezuelan drug boat
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump alleged that "narcoterrorists" were on the boat and that they were carrying illegal drugs destined for the United States.
items.content: President Donald Trump alleged that "narcoterrorists" were on the boat and that they were carrying illegal drugs destined for the United States.

ai_summary: Trump is on a second state visit to the UK, receiving royal treatment from King Charles.
Protests and image projections regarding Trump's ties to Jeffrey Epstein are occurring.
Four arrests were made after images of Trump and Epstein were projected on Windsor Castle.
The visit is met with controversy over the Epstein scandal and political fallout.
The UK government is rolling out a red carpet to win over the mercurial leader.

items.title: Kirk suspect, Tyler Robinson, faces death penalty for aggravated murder charge
items.standfirst: Tyler Robinson fired a single fatal shot from the rooftop of a building overlooking the outdoor venue where Kirk was speaking to about 3,000 people on Sept. 10, investigators say. Afterward, prosecutors say he texted with the partner, who he lived with near St. George, Utah, about 240 miles (387 kilometers) southwest of the campus.
items.content: Tyler Robinson fired a single fatal shot from the rooftop of a building overlooking the outdoor venue where Kirk was speaking to about 3,000 people on Sept. 10, investigators say. Afterward, prosecutors say he texted with the partner, who he lived with near St. George, Utah, about 240 miles (387 kilometers) southwest of the campus.

items.title: Kirk suspect faces death penalty for aggravated murder charge
items.standfirst: The suspect in the killing of Charlie Kirk appeared in court Tuesday charged with the conservative activist's murder, as prosecutors said they were seeking the death penalty for a crime that has shaken the United States.
items.content: The suspect in the killing of Charlie Kirk appeared in court Tuesday charged with the conservative activist's murder, as prosecutors said they were seeking the death penalty for a crime that has shaken the United States.

Robinson fired a single shot, killing Kirk, according to investigators.

clusters.title: Israeli troops push into Gaza City, forcing Palestinians to flee their assault
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel Launches Ground Offensive in Gaza City

items.title: Israeli troops push into Gaza City, forcing Palestinians to flee their assault
items.standfirst: Israel pressed ahead Wednesday with an intense new ground offensive in Gaza City, defying international condemnation and sending hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fleeing the devastated, famine-stricken area
items.content: Israel pressed ahead Wednesday with an intense new ground offensive in Gaza City, defying international condemnation and sending hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fleeing the devastated, famine-stricken area

items.title: Israel military presses on with its new ground offensive on Gaza City
items.standfirst: Israeli forces pressed on with a new ground offensive in Gaza City Wednesday as strikes overnight across the Palestinian territory killed at least 16 people, including women and children, hospital officials said.
items.content: Israeli forces pressed on with a new ground offensive in Gaza City Wednesday as strikes overnight across the Palestinian territory killed at least 16 people, including women and children, hospital officials said.

items.title: Israel launches ground offensive deep inside Gaza City | First Thing
items.standfirst: Benjamin Netanyahu says goals of offensive are ‘defeating the enemy and evacuating the population’. Plus, suspect in Charlie Kirk killing charged with aggravated murderGood morning.Israel began its long-threatened ground offensive in Gaza City on Tuesday, sending tanks and remote-controlled armoured cars packed with explosives into its streets, in defiance of international criticism and a UN commission’s finding that it was committing genocide in the Palestinian territory.What are Palestinians in Gaza City reporting? Many have been forcibly displaced multiple times in “unbearable” conditions and some say they will remain in Gaza City despite the risks. Fatima al-Zahra Sahweil, a researcher, said: “There is not a single day without bombings and deaths in the south, even in the so-called humanitarian zones that the army declared. So, would I just be running from death to death?”This is a developing story. Follow on our liveblog.Why have prosecutors said they will pursue the death penalty? Gray said the aggravating circumstances were the 31-year-old Kirk’s “political expression” and the fact that children were present to witness the killing.What do we know about Robinson’s possible motivations? He is alleged to have sent a text message to his roommate reading: “I had enough of his hatred. Some hate can’t be negotiated out.” Continue reading...
items.content: Benjamin Netanyahu says goals of offensive are ‘defeating the enemy and evacuating the population’. Plus, suspect in Charlie Kirk killing charged with aggravated murderGood morning.Israel began its long-threatened ground offensive in Gaza City on Tuesday, sending tanks and remote-controlled armoured cars packed with explosives into its streets, in defiance of international criticism and a UN commission’s finding that it was committing genocide in the Palestinian territory.What are Palestinians in Gaza City reporting? Many have been forcibly displaced multiple times in “unbearable” conditions and some say they will remain in Gaza City despite the risks. Fatima al-Zahra Sahweil, a researcher, said: “There is not a single day without bombings and deaths in the south, even in the so-called humanitarian zones that the army declared. So, would I just be running from death to death?”This is a developing story. Follow on our liveblog.Why have prosecutors said they will pursue the death penalty? Gray said the aggravating circumstances were the 31-year-old Kirk’s “political expression” and the fact that children were present to witness the killing.What do we know about Robinson’s possible motivations? He is alleged to have sent a text message to his roommate reading: “I had enough of his hatred. Some hate can’t be negotiated out.” Continue reading...

items.title: Thousands of Palestinians flee as Israeli troops push into Gaza City
items.standfirst: Israel says its aim is to defeat up to 3,000 Hamas fighters who remain there, but the offensive has drawn international condemnation.
items.content: Israel says its aim is to defeat up to 3,000 Hamas fighters who remain there, but the offensive has drawn international condemnation.

items.title: Israeli military ground offensive moves in Gaza City as Palestinians flee
items.standfirst: Israel launched its offensive in Gaza City on Tuesday, vowing to overwhelm a city already in ruins from nearly two years of war as thousands of Palestinians fled in vehicles strapped with mattresses and other belongings that clogged a coastal road.
items.content: Israel launched its offensive in Gaza City on Tuesday, vowing to overwhelm a city already in ruins from nearly two years of war as thousands of Palestinians fled in vehicles strapped with mattresses and other belongings that clogged a coastal road.

items.title: LIVE: Israel kills dozens of Palestinians as Gaza City invasion intensifies
items.standfirst: More than 30 people killed across the Gaza Strip since dawn as Israeli assault to seize urban centre draws condemnation.
items.content: More than 30 people killed across the Gaza Strip since dawn as Israeli assault to seize urban centre draws condemnation.

items.title: 'One million people in Gaza City subjected to relentless bombing by Israeli forces'
items.standfirst: Israel has launched its offensive in Gaza City, vowing to overwhelm a city already in ruins from nearly two years of war. The operation into the largest Palestinian city escalated a conflict that has roiled the Middle East and likely pushed any ceasefire with Hamas farther out of reach. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, François Picard welcomes Claire San Filippo, MSF Emergency Coordinator at Doctors Without Borders.
items.content: Israel has launched its offensive in Gaza City, vowing to overwhelm a city already in ruins from nearly two years of war. The operation into the largest Palestinian city escalated a conflict that has roiled the Middle East and likely pushed any ceasefire with Hamas farther out of reach. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, François Picard welcomes Claire San Filippo, MSF Emergency Coordinator at Doctors Without Borders.

items.title: Dehumanisation: How Israel is able to commit its genocide in Gaza
items.standfirst: Israel has dehumanised Palestinians for decades, eventually leading to the current Gaza genocide, say analysts.
items.content: Israel has dehumanised Palestinians for decades, eventually leading to the current Gaza genocide, say analysts.

items.title: Israel launches ground offensive in Gaza City
items.standfirst: Thousands of Palestinians fled from Gaza City after Israel launched a ground offensive. It comes as a new report today from an independent United Nations commission concluded Israel is committing genocide. NBC News’ Matt Bradley reports.
items.content: Thousands of Palestinians fled from Gaza City after Israel launched a ground offensive. It comes as a new report today from an independent United Nations commission concluded Israel is committing genocide. NBC News’ Matt Bradley reports.

You can read our latest report here:Israel launches ground offensive deep inside Gaza CityWafa, the Palestinian news agency, has been told by medical sources that at least 38 Palestinian people, including women and children, have been killed by Israeli forces since dawn today.As well as facing relentless bombardments, Gaza City, the biggest built-up area of the territory, is being gripped by a famine caused by Israel’s restrictions on aid. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel Committing Genocide in Gaza Says UN Commission
items.standfirst: Israel rejects UN Commission finding that it is committing genocide in Gaza.
items.content: Israel rejects UN Commission finding that it is committing genocide in Gaza.

items.title: Israel launches ground offensive deep inside Gaza City
items.standfirst: IDF says advance aims to ‘dismantle Hamas’s grip’ as UN report says Israel has committed genocide in territoryIsrael unleashed its long-threatened ground offensive in Gaza City on Tuesday, sending tanks and remote-controlled armoured cars packed with explosives into its streets, in defiance of international criticism and the findings of a UN commission that it was committing genocide in the Palestinian territory.“Gaza is burning. The IDF is striking terror infrastructure with an iron fist,” Israel’s defence minister, Israel Katz, wrote on X as the attack was launched in the early hours of the morning, adding: “We will not relent until the mission is completed.” Continue reading...
items.content: IDF says advance aims to ‘dismantle Hamas’s grip’ as UN report says Israel has committed genocide in territoryIsrael unleashed its long-threatened ground offensive in Gaza City on Tuesday, sending tanks and remote-controlled armoured cars packed with explosives into its streets, in defiance of international criticism and the findings of a UN commission that it was committing genocide in the Palestinian territory.“Gaza is burning. The IDF is striking terror infrastructure with an iron fist,” Israel’s defence minister, Israel Katz, wrote on X as the attack was launched in the early hours of the morning, adding: “We will not relent until the mission is completed.” Continue reading...

items.title: Israel has committed genocide in Gaza, says UN commission of inquiry
items.standfirst: Report cites scale of killings and aid blockages, and calls on member countries to punish those responsibleA UN commission has found that Israel is committing genocide in Gaza, citing tens of thousands of civilian deaths and massive destruction, and has called on member countries to punish those responsible for it.The United Nations independent international commission of inquiry (COI), which does not speak on behalf of the UN, found that “genocide is occurring in Gaza and is continuing to occur”, said its head, Navi Pillay. Continue reading...
items.content: Report cites scale of killings and aid blockages, and calls on member countries to punish those responsibleA UN commission has found that Israel is committing genocide in Gaza, citing tens of thousands of civilian deaths and massive destruction, and has called on member countries to punish those responsible for it.The United Nations independent international commission of inquiry (COI), which does not speak on behalf of the UN, found that “genocide is occurring in Gaza and is continuing to occur”, said its head, Navi Pillay. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel is committing genocide in Gaza, U.N. report finds
items.standfirst: Israel is committing genocide against Palestinians in Gaza, a United Nations commission said Tuesday, calling on the international community to end the campaign and punish the top officials it found responsible for inciting it
items.content: Israel is committing genocide against Palestinians in Gaza, a United Nations commission said Tuesday, calling on the international community to end the campaign and punish the top officials it found responsible for inciting it

items.title: Bowen: UN commission report on genocide is blunt indictment of Israel's actions in Gaza
items.standfirst: A new report accuses Israel of committing genocide in Gaza, in "the strongest and most authoritative UN finding to date".
items.content: A new report accuses Israel of committing genocide in Gaza, in "the strongest and most authoritative UN finding to date".

ai_summary: Israel launched a new ground offensive in Gaza City, defying international condemnation.
Overnight strikes across Gaza killed at least 16 people, including women and children.
Palestinians are fleeing the devastated area due to the offensive.
Benjamin Netanyahu says the offensive aims to defeat the enemy and evacuate the population.
The suspect in the Kirk killing is facing the death penalty due to "political expression."

clusters.title: Madeleine McCann suspect freed from German prison
clusters.neutral_headline: Madeleine McCann Suspect Released from German Prison

items.title: Madeleine McCann suspect freed from German prison
items.standfirst: Christian Brückner has never been charged with any crime in relation to the McCann case.
items.content: Christian Brückner has never been charged with any crime in relation to the McCann case.

items.title: Main suspect in Madeleine McCann case released from German prison
items.standfirst: Authorities say they no longer have legal justification to hold Christian Brückner in jail after serving rape sentenceThe main suspect in the disappearance of Madeleine McCann was freed on Wednesday as German authorities said they no longer had legal justification to hold him in jail.Christian Brückner, 49, was released from prison in Sehnde, northern Germany, after serving a sentence for the rape of an American woman, then 72 years old, in Portugal in 2005, journalists at the scene reported. Continue reading...
items.content: Authorities say they no longer have legal justification to hold Christian Brückner in jail after serving rape sentenceThe main suspect in the disappearance of Madeleine McCann was freed on Wednesday as German authorities said they no longer had legal justification to hold him in jail.Christian Brückner, 49, was released from prison in Sehnde, northern Germany, after serving a sentence for the rape of an American woman, then 72 years old, in Portugal in 2005, journalists at the scene reported. Continue reading...

items.title: Suspect in UK toddler disappearance is released after serving time in unrelated case
items.standfirst: A German national under investigation in the disappearance of British toddler Madeleine McCann 18 years ago was freed from prison Wednesday after serving a sentence in an unrelated case, police said.
items.content: A German national under investigation in the disappearance of British toddler Madeleine McCann 18 years ago was freed from prison Wednesday after serving a sentence in an unrelated case, police said.(Image credit: Markus Schreiber)

items.title: Madeleine McCann suspect released after serving rape sentence
items.standfirst: The convicted sex offender Christian B has been released from prison after a prosecutor failed to find enough evidence to charge him in the Madeleine McCann case.
items.content: The convicted sex offender Christian B has been released from prison after a prosecutor failed to find enough evidence to charge him in the Madeleine McCann case.

ai_summary: Christian Brückner, the main suspect, was released from prison in Germany.
He had served a sentence for the rape of an American woman.
Authorities no longer had legal justification to hold him.
Brückner has never been charged in connection to the McCann case.
He was released after serving time in an unrelated case.

clusters.title: Peru evacuates 1,600 tourists from Machu Picchu amid protest
clusters.neutral_headline: Tourists Evacuated from Machu Picchu Amid Protests

items.title: Peru evacuates 1,600 tourists from Machu Picchu amid protest
items.standfirst: Peru has evacuated around 1,600 tourists from a train station that serves the Inca citadel of Machu Picchu after a local protest escalated into clashes with police. UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1983, the ancient fortified complex receives around 4,500 visitors a day, many of them foreigners, according to the tourism ministry.
items.content: Peru has evacuated around 1,600 tourists from a train station that serves the Inca citadel of Machu Picchu after a local protest escalated into clashes with police. UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1983, the ancient fortified complex receives around 4,500 visitors a day, many of them foreigners, according to the tourism ministry.

items.title: Hundreds of Machu Picchu tourists stranded
items.standfirst: Hundreds of tourists have been left stranded near Peru's ancient Inca citadel of Machu Picchu after rail services were suspended because protesters blocked the route with rocks.
items.content: Hundreds of tourists have been left stranded near Peru's ancient Inca citadel of Machu Picchu after rail services were suspended because protesters blocked the route with rocks.

items.title: Rocks on train tracks strand 900 Machu Picchu tourists amid protest
items.standfirst: About 1,400 visitors were evacuated but hundreds were left stuck because of action linked to bus contract dispute, say Peru authoritiesAt least 900 tourists were stranded near the ancient Inca citadel of Machu Picchu on Tuesday, Peru’s tourism minister said, after a passenger train service was suspended due to a protest.PeruRail said service was suspended on Monday because the route in Peru’s mountainous Cusco region had been blocked by “rocks of various sizes” as residents clashed with authorities and bus companies. PeruRail’s local unit also said “third parties” had excavated part of its rail route, which affected the track’s stability and slowed down the evacuation of tourists. Continue reading...
items.content: About 1,400 visitors were evacuated but hundreds were left stuck because of action linked to bus contract dispute, say Peru authoritiesAt least 900 tourists were stranded near the ancient Inca citadel of Machu Picchu on Tuesday, Peru’s tourism minister said, after a passenger train service was suspended due to a protest.PeruRail said service was suspended on Monday because the route in Peru’s mountainous Cusco region had been blocked by “rocks of various sizes” as residents clashed with authorities and bus companies. PeruRail’s local unit also said “third parties” had excavated part of its rail route, which affected the track’s stability and slowed down the evacuation of tourists. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Peru evacuated around 1,600 tourists from Machu Picchu due to protests.
Rail services were suspended due to protesters blocking the route.
Hundreds of tourists were left stranded near the Inca citadel.
Protests escalated into clashes with police.
The action is linked to a bus contract dispute.

clusters.title: US workers fired over Charlie Kirk social media posts
clusters.neutral_headline: Employees Fired Over Charlie Kirk Social Media Posts

items.title: US workers fired over Charlie Kirk social media posts
items.standfirst: United Airlines, Nasdaq, Washington Post and others dismiss employees in aftermath of conservative activist’s murder
items.content: United Airlines, Nasdaq, Washington Post and others dismiss employees in aftermath of conservative activist’s murder

items.title: WIRED Roundup: How Charlie Kirk Changed Conservative Media
items.standfirst: On this episode of "Uncanny Valley," we discuss the legacy of Charlie Kirk and the aftermath of his murder.
items.content: On this episode of "Uncanny Valley," we discuss the legacy of Charlie Kirk and the aftermath of his murder.

items.title: Washington Post columnist says she was fired for social media posts after Kirk was killed
items.standfirst: Karen Attiah says she was fired for “endangering” her colleagues.
items.content: Washington Post columnist Karen Attiah said on Monday that she was fired from the publication over social media posts she made following the killing of Charlie Kirk. Writing in a lengthy Substack post, Attiah said she was dismissed over her posts on Bluesky that she says were deemed to be "unacceptable,” “gross misconduct” and that endangered the physical safety of her colleagues. “They rushed to fire me without even a conversation,” she wrote. “This was not only a hasty overreach, but a violation of the very standards of journalistic fairness and rigor the Post claims to uphold.” A spokesperson for the Washington Post declined to comment on personnel matters. The Washington Post's public social media policyrequires employees to ensure any posts made do not make "reasonable people question their editorial independence, nor make reasonable people question The Post’s ability to cover issues fairly." The guidance also urges staffers to "avoid curating your feeds in ways that suggest you have a partisan point of view on an issue The Post covers," though the policy specifically states that does not apply to columnists, critics and other practitioners of opinion journalism posting as part of their work. Earlier this year, the publication shifted its opinion section to focus on supporting “personal liberties and free markets.” Owner Jeff Bezos said at the time that a “broad-based opinion section” was no longer needed because a diversity of opinions were available online. In a statement, the Washington Post guild called Attiah's firing "unjust" and said it would continue to defend her rights. "The Post not only flagrantly disregarded standard disciplinary processes, it also undermined its own mandate to be a champion of free speech," the guild said in a post on X. "The right to speak freely is the ultimate personal liberty and the foundation of Karen’s 11-year career at The Post." Some of Attiah’s social media posts condemned political violence but also highlighted Kirk’s divisive comments on Black women. In her only post directly mentioning Kirk, she quoted the Turning Point USA founder’s comments that Black women lack “brain processing power.” “I made clear that not performing over-the-top grief for white men who espouse violence was not the same as endorsing violence against them,” Attiah said. Attiah, who started her career at The Washington Post in 2014, said the publication “silenced" her. She warned her firing is part of a larger trend. “What happened to me is part of a broader purge of Black voices from academia, business, government, and media — a historical pattern as dangerous as it is shameful — and tragic,” she said.

ai_summary: Employees were fired over social media posts after Charlie Kirk's murder.
United Airlines, Nasdaq, and the Washington Post dismissed employees.
A Washington Post columnist says she was fired for her posts.
The columnist says she was fired for "endangering" her colleagues.
The aftermath of the murder is impacting employment.

clusters.title: New lab results show Putin critic Navalny was poisoned in jail, wife says

items.title: New lab results show Putin critic Navalny was poisoned in jail, wife says
items.standfirst: In a video posted on YouTube on Wednesday, Yulia, the widow of Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny said that laboratory results from "two countries" proved he was "poisoned". The Kremlin has previously denied that Navalny was killed on President Vladimir Putin's orders and said it was unaware of Yulia's claims.
